title: Cryogenic STEM in the World of Relaxor Ferroelectric Materials
content: Inspired by Prof. Lena Kourkoutis’s pioneering work in CryoSTEM [1-3], this talk will explore how the temperature-dependent local structure of relaxor ferroelectric materials gives rise to their unique properties. Although relaxor behavior had been commonly attributed to polar nanoregions—nanoscale domains embedded within a non-polar matrix—giving rise to their diffuse dielectric and piezoelectric properties across a broad temperature range, only recently have direct insights into fundamental changes at the atomic scale been possible. Prior models, for example, have fallen short in explaining relaxor behavior. While X-rays, neutrons, and electrons diffuse scattering techniques have been used extensively to explore temperature-dependent polar behavior, these methods capture the global and local average structures. Atomic-scale resolution microscopy is required to help fully elucidate the origin of relaxor properties by providing direct connections between local chemistry and structure [4], particularly as a function of temperature.
